column4: hi all, just wondering if anyone can help with sed awk grep? im looking for a one-liner to shirt the last char of a line to the front of the line
why would you want to do this?  Sounds like homework...
you don't need anything other than bash
I will be less cryptic for you: bash substring
really it doesn't make sense to use sed for this...
you're using regular expressions to extract substrings given by position.  Kind of silly
so what make sense to you

you know the old joke about regular expressions? "Some people, when confronted with a problem, think 'I know, I'll use regular expressions.'   Now they have two problems." Anyway, it's fine but I would suggest you just use bash's ability to extract substrings.  Here is an example: foo="this is a line"; echo ${foo:3:5} .  There's some documentation here if you want:
thanks for the link, how would you # cat file | swap last to first.
did you figure out how to do what you asked on a line using bash?  Or are you not really interested?
still not working as expected, but working on it! if you have a solution / example i am very interested!
if you take the time to read about bash substring extraction, the answer should be pretty straightforward...
but llutz_'s sed solution should work too... it's just not as pure as I would like :P
so what is your example, im reading but not getting it yet ;)

I gave my example: foo="this is a line"; echo ${foo:3:5}.   That gives you substring starting at 3 and taking 5 characters.  But you want "last character" + "first character to second to last character".  So you now have 2 substrings that you need to figure out how to extract
